Award.AwardTitle: International Symposium on Observations and Modeling of Land Surface Water and Energy Exchanges across Scales: Learning from the past and looking to the future
Award.AbstractNarration:
The planned symposium will focus on advances in observations and modeling of land surface exchanges of both water and energy. It will explore societal connections to operational hydrology, including data assimilation approaches for improving hydrological forecasting for water management, as well as for drought and flood prediction. It is expected that the symposium will attract more than 150 attendees from around the world, including from developing regions. The symposium keynote/invited speakers will be specifically asked to reflect on past progress, future challenges, and emerging new opportunities, which will form the basis for a synthesis paper that will serve as a major milestone in hydrologic research.

In the past ~25 years there has been an expansion of research in process understanding, observations and predictions at a range of scales related to land surface water and energy exchanges. The space-time variability in precipitation interacts with the spatial heterogeneity of landscapes to produce spatially and temporally variable fields of runoff and soil moisture. This variability impacts many areas of hydrologic research including flood and drought estimation, water resource management, climate change impact assessments, and water quality predictions. Land-atmosphere interactions also affect the linkages between land surface states and fluxes, as well as transport through the atmospheric surface and boundary layers and the associated modulation of convection, clouds and precipitation. These interactions operate over decision-relevant time scales, from diurnal (weather) to seasonal and inter-annual (climate). The planned symposium will review and synthesis progress and new knowledge in this field. The meeting will bring together multiple generations of scientists covering the scope of the problem. The results focusing on hydrologic predictability and its relationship to land surface memory, land-atmosphere interactions, global teleconnections and climate predictability as well as the human impacts on hydrologic variability and extremes, and associated coupled human-water system feedbacks will be a significant contribution to the field of hydrometeorology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the project is to hold an international symposium on “Observations and Modeling of Land Surface Water and Energy Exchanges across Scales: Learning from the past and looking to the future”. The focus of the symposium is on our current understanding and future prospects for improving the observation, modeling, and prediction for decision making of the spatial heterogeneities and temporal variability that arise from the nonlinear dynamical interactions between the land surface and the atmosphere, how they manifest in hydrologic variability at a range of scales, including extremes. Improved modeling and observational capability from local to the global scales, and data-model synthesis through data assimilation techniques, have the power to inform our understanding of hydrologic processes, and their connection to climate, and how that can inform and improve our ability to predict extreme hydrological events, and understand longer-term changes.

To meet our overall goal, an international symposium was held on June 2-3, 2016 at Princeton University. The symposium was attended by about 150 people from the US and internationally (see appended list). The symposium was organized around the following seven themes:

1. Scaling and heterogeneity of hydrologic systems

2. Hydrologic and coupled hydroclimate predictions, from real-time to climate scales, and their applications

3. Global water and energy cycles

4. Remote sensing retrievals and their applications in hydrology

5. Land surface model developments - LDAS systems, hyper-resolution modeling, data assimilation

6. Hydrologic predictability and its relationship to land surface memory, land-atmosphere interactions, global teleconnections and climate predictability

7. Human impacts on hydrologic variability and extremes, and associated coupled human-water system feedbacks

There were eight 90-minute oral sessions, as well as dedicated poster sessions, that addressed the themes outlined above, as well as a final synthesis session. Each session comprised of four oral presentations (2 keynote/2 invited) of 20-minute duration. The keynote/invited speakers devoted a substantial part of their talks to reflect on past progress, future challenges, and emerging new opportunities. The speakers were specifically invited on the basis of their track record in pushing the boundaries of research, and the ability to offer a forward-looking visionary talk on the session topic.  A final synthesis session, “Tacking stock, moving forward”, provided the opportunity for rapporteurs to summarize each of the sessions and a synthesis panel discussed the overall outcomes.

A special issue of Hydrology and Earth System Sciences (HESS) journal was organized to mark the occasion with contributions following the oral and poster topics and ranging from review papers, forward looking visionary papers as well as research articles. The HESS special issue is dedicated to Professor Eric F Wood, as a tribute to his contributions to hydrologic science and applications, and his leadership of the hydrologic community over a 40 year career. Currently there have been 32 papers have been published for the special issue.
